content: The curr_chunk is about the "Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission." The Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2000 is amended to grant the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission powers to make expenditures, solicit contributions, hold hearings, and enter into agreements for the purpose of carrying out its duties. The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission is granted powers to make expenditures, solicit contributions, hold hearings, enter into contracts for specialized services, and take necessary actions to fulfill its duties. Specialized services can be obtained and paid for without following certain provisions of the United States Code. The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission has the authority to accept gifts of property, request federal cooperation, and empower members and agents to take necessary actions for the memorial. The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission may appoint an architect to represent them on governmental boards for selecting firms to design the memorial. Authorized members or agents providing services are considered federal government employees for legal purposes. The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission appoints an Executive Director and staff for support services, with travel expenses covered for Commission members. The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission appoints an Executive Director and staff without adherence to typical federal hiring and pay regulations, with limitations on pay rates for staff members. The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission may pay staff at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission, and it can obtain support services from the General Services Administration. The Commission is also allowed to enter into cooperative agreements with Federal agencies and State entities. The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission can obtain temporary, intermittent, and part-time services at specified rates. It is also permitted to accept volunteer services despite certain limitations. The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission can accept volunteer services without compensation, reimburse volunteers for local travel and office supplies, and provide travel expenses as authorized by law. Volunteers are considered as such under the Volunteer Protection Act of 1997, with exceptions. The Volunteer Protection Act of 1997 does not apply to claims against certain volunteers. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section. The Volunteer Protection Act of 1997 does not apply to claims against certain volunteers. Passed the House of Representatives on October 22, 2007.
